10.text:
You thought that just because we’d made
our rounds throughout our solar system that

13.text: we were done with our intergalactic travel?

17.text:
There’s so much more in that deep vast blackness
that will keep us busy for some time to come

21.text:
– such as these 10 incredibly bizarre and
unusual objects that have either been found

27.text: in or have come from space!

30.text:
Rogue Planets
Imagine being left to float all by your lonesome

34.text:
in space, pulled from your planetary system
by a gas giant’s gravitation pull.

39.text:
You’re a rogue planet, a nomadic mass that
orbits the galaxy’s core instead of a star,

44.text: kind of like a ship without a port.

47.text:
There are believed to be billions of rogue
planets in the Milky Way alone, though some

51.text:
scientists theorize some of them, known as
sub-brown dwarfs, are more akin to stars than

58.text:
These homeless planets are normally aimless
and harmless, though one individual from the

62.text:
University of Louisiana, Daniel Whitmire,
spoke out about a mysterious “Planet Nine”

67.text:
or Nibiru which could cause an extinction
event on Earth and is possibly responsible

75.text:
Gliese 581g
Back in 2010, Gliese 581g took astronomers

82.text:
They believe they had found a planet beyond
our solar system that was so similar to Earth

87.text: that it could be habitable by human life.

90.text:
Gliese 581g was thought to orbit its own star
and came in at about the same size and temperature

95.text:
as Earth, but some astronomers think there’s
a big issue with the exoplanet – they don’t

102.text:
Speaking against the Pro-Gliese 581g crowd,
astronomers like Paul Robertson claim that

108.text:
the would-be Super Earth is nothing more than
a magnetic outburst from a star, mislabeled

115.text:
While there are still those that believe 581g
is as originally thought, the potential exoplanet

121.text:
was removed from the Habitable Exoplanet Catalogue
of the Planetary Habitability Laboratory of

127.text: the University of Puerto Rico at Arecibo.

130.text:
Dark Matter
It’s strange to think that, even today,

134.text:
with the technology we have, about 27% of
the universe’s mass simply cannot be observed.

140.text:
That quarter portion has come to be known
as dark matter, a mysterious unknown of our

145.text:
universe that is more easily distinguished
by what it is not than what it is.

150.text:
Popular theory states that dark matter is
nothing observable, such as baryonic clouds,

155.text:
and is nothing that emits light, ruling out
any star and planetary formations.

161.text:
Possibilities are said to include dim brown
dwarfs, neutrino stars, white dwarves, or

166.text:
even supermassive black holes, but the most
considered prospects are Weakly Interacting

174.text:
These particles are said to have up to 100
times the mass of a proton but weaker interactions,

183.text:
Magnetars
Space isn’t just filled with peaceful nomad

190.text:
There are also volatile, explosive stars that
erupt with no warning.

194.text:
Sometimes it’s magnetars, magnetic stars
that aren’t powered by nuclear fusion.

200.text:
These unique stars are unlike their sparkling
brethren and have an unfathomable magnetic

205.text:
field that is stronger than any other object
in the universe, even man-made magnetics.

210.text:
They’re said to be formed from a perfect
line-up of the star’s spin, temperature,

214.text:
and magnetic field when collapsing into a
neutron star and can be incredibly dangerous

219.text:
at a range of approximately 630 miles or 1,000
kilometers.

224.text: As of 2016, only 29 magnetars have been discovered.

229.text:
Black Hole
They’re pretty well known to even the common

232.text:
Earthling, but that doesn’t make the concept
of the Black Hole any weirder.

237.text:
Hollywood often uses them as a means of transdimensional
travel, but seeing as how nothing is able

242.text:
to escape from inside of it – not even light
– that’s a highly unlikely scenario.

248.text:
These black voids, detectable only with specially
designed telescopes and by gauging strong

253.text:
gravitational effects, are typically formed
when a large star collapses on itself, though

258.text:
smaller and supermassive black holes are believed
to have formed at the same time as their galaxy.

264.text:
The unknown of black holes can make them mystifying
and terrifying, but there are no black holes

269.text:
near enough for Earth to fall into and our
Sun is not large enough to create one.

276.text:
Black Widow Pulsar
Like the creepy crawly black widow spider

280.text:
that it’s named after, the Black Widow Pulsar
is known to essentially “devour” any low-mass

285.text: stars that it comes in close proximity with.

289.text:
Pulsars are formed through a supernova, when
a neutron star is left behind and starts to

295.text:
As they spin, they emit radio waves, X-rays,
gamma rays, and visible light rays until they

301.text:
begin to slow down, at which point the emissions
become weaker.

304.text:
To repower themselves, the pulsars will essentially
eat away at their companion star’s material

310.text:
until, after millions of years, only the refueled
pulsar is left.

316.text:
Pillars of Creation
Like eerie skeletal fingers of some galactic

320.text:
God, the Pillars of Creation seem to stretch
out into the colorful vastness.

325.text:
The beautifully horrific image, likely the
creepiest picture ever of space, came from

330.text:
the Hubble Space Telescope and depicts interstellar
gasses and dust found 7,000 light years from

338.text:
As the name suggests, the odd picture depicts
creation as the gas and dust are believed

343.text: to be in the process of forming new stars.

346.text:
As if the image wasn’t imposing enough,
the fingers of the formation are larger than

353.text:
Updated, 3D images of the gaseous structure
shows that they are slowly falling apart and

358.text:
may only have another 3 million years left
in their lifespan.

363.text:
Sagittarius B2
Who said the universe can’t be delicious?

368.text:
Okay, probably nobody because it’s a silly
thing to declare, but if they had, we would

373.text:
fire back with the unusualness that is Sagittarius
B2.

377.text:
No, this isn’t a new vitamin, it’s a colossal
dust cloud 390 light years from the center

384.text:
of our galaxy that’s comprised of a large
portion of ethyl formate.

388.text:
This specific chemical compound smells of
rum and is partially responsible for the way

395.text:
It’s believed that the ethyl alcohol attaches
to dust particles left over from a star formation

400.text:
and, when the dust moves towards the star,
the alcohol heats up and becomes its own gas.

409.text: The best thing to happen to space pirates?

413.text:
Galactic Cannibalism
What looks like 2 galaxies merging into 1

417.text:
mega galaxy or some bizarre mating ritual,
is actually similar to the Black Widow Pulsar,

425.text:
The concept of galactic cannibalism comes
into play when two galaxies collide and are

430.text:
left with little momentum to continue traveling
on their path.

434.text:
Without the oomph to push forward, the galaxies
just kind of settle into one another and begin

439.text: to merge, typically forming an irregular galaxy.

443.text:
Known instances of galactic cannibalism can
be seen with the Mice Galaxies, Whirlpool

451.text:
Brightness Fluctuations in KIC 8462852
If you’ve been waiting for a time to use

457.text:
that Giorgio A. Tsoukalos’ Ancient Aliens
meme when discussing the fluctuation in brightness

462.text:
of F-type star KIC 8462852, now would be the
perfect time.

468.text:
Typically, any sort of change in brightness
is associated with the presence of a planet

472.text:
– in fact, it’s one way exoplanets can
be detected; but the approximate 15% drop

478.text:
in starlight is considerably greater than
the 1% caused by a planet the same size as

485.text:
The object would have to be massive, something
that scientists believe they would have identified

490.text:
So, they’re left considering an incredibly
unusual possibility: Aliens.
